@sjie

I totally agree with you! I think this feature is better suited at broker side, first reason as you said, would be simplicity and much less code on the overall pulsar project. Second reason is clock dependent at back end side instead at client side, giving more flexibility to an administrator. Third reason would be to save a lot of I/O wasted for delivering messages not expired.

This pr as is, the only thing that adds at client side is the ability to pass an optional parameter (receiver delay) to the broker, which is a period of time to let the broker do the calculation of which messages are expired.
If all of you agrees to go on with this pr I'm able to add this parameter to the rest of the clients, maybe on a dedicated pr?

In my opinion there is one thing we need to solve before going on with this pr, as @codelipenghui said, publish time is client-generated, we need to change this in order to set this parameter at broker level to use it in a safer way. Do you see any problem doing this change?

Now the Go client Producer Send function is as follow

```go
func (p *producer) Send(ctx context.Context, msg ProducerMessage) error {
```

Just as you said, the message ID is not return. 

To be compatible, a new Method is necessary. We might need more discussion about this.

Yes, the state is shared between the two instances. When you do a put/get inside the Context inside a function the real-key is the fully qualified function name + the key that you specify. This means that the key is visible to not just other instances of the function, but to other functions as well. However the Context api currently doesnt provide any way of accessing some other functions' keys.

Thank you. Is it thread-safe to use state in parallel function instances?

> If all of you agrees to go on with this pr I'm able to add this parameter to the rest of the clients, maybe on a dedicated pr?

+1 from me

> as @codelipenghui said, publish time is client-generated, we need to change this in order to set this parameter at broker level to use it in a safer way. Do you see any problem doing this change?

that seems to be okay to me. however for backward compatability consideration, I would suggest adding a flag on producer to control set publisher time or not at client side. If producer doesn't set publish time, the broker will then set the publish time.

@sijie I've seen the wiki page of tiered storage previously. It's not the same as Pravega:

- It's not an auto-tiering solution. User has to migrate to low tier storage manually through api. An unified storage for both streaming and batching should be able to automatically process these flow for users
- The kinds of storage solutions for Pulsar is limited, many kinds of storage such as HDFS, Ceph,...,etc are not supported.
- Transaction for entire stream

I don't think implementing features of Pravega to Pulsar is difficult, while providing feature of Pulsar to Pravega is much more difficult. Here's a [slide](https://www.slideshare.net/Hadoop_Summit/an-elastic-batchand-streamprocessing-stack-with-pravega-and-apache-flink)  of having Pravega work together with Flink, which I think it has the same vision with Pulsar.

> It's not an auto-tiering solution. User has to migrate to low tier storage manually through api. An unified storage for both streaming and batching should be able to automatically process these flow for users

1) Pulsar has auto-tiering by namespaces. Pulsar is a multi-tenant system, so everything is controlled per tenant/namespace, not per cluster. A user can configure offloading to tiered storage by namespaces. I believe it can configure to auto-offload at size-based policy or interval-based policy. If it is not provided, it should be trivial to add that.
2) Not every user need tiered storage. 

> many kinds of storage such as HDFS, Ceph,...,etc are not supported.

All the mechanism for tiered storages are in places. Everyone can contribute the offloader to offload pulsar to the storage system he/she is using.

HDFS offloader is under development. But if you have more specific requirements, I would suggest you creating specific github issues for them. We can work with you on priotizing them. 

> Transaction for entire stream

Transaction is a separate story that is under discussion and development.

Thank you. There are some other design features for auto tiering:
1. Retention policy, describes a policy about how much data to retain within a stream. This is similar with what Pulsar has done to let customer configure how data was migrated to low tier storage.
2. Scaling policy, describes if and under what circumstances a stream should `automatically` scale its number of segments. This is a bit more complicated: the controller monitors traffic of stream segment writing requests, if some thresholds have been reached, it will decide how to scale. There are two types of traffic reports that can be received for segments. First type identifies if a segment should be scaled up (split) and second type identifies if a segment should be scaled down. For segments eligible for scale up, controller immediately posts request for segment scale up in the request stream for request event processor to process. However, for scale down, Controller needs to wait for at least two neighboring segments to become eligible for scale down. This auto scaling could be seen [here](https://github.com/pravega/pravega/blob/master/documentation/src/docs/pravega-concepts.md#elastic-streams-auto-scaling) with more detail.
![Uploading 图片.png…](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pravega/pravega/master/documentation/src/docs/img/segment.split.merge.overtime.new.png)

@sijie I notice that Pravega will also be presented at Flink Forward in the same room, just after your presentation, perhaps you could get something more face by face :)

@yingfeng 

> Retention policy, 

it is already supported in Pulsar. I would suggest you taking a closer look at Pulsar and creating individual tasks for the features you would like to see in Pulsar. Pulsar and Pravega are different projects, Pulsar has a broader vision than Pravega. It unifies both messaging (queueing and streaming) and storage. 

> Scaling policy,

Pulsar provides all the mechanisms to scaling up and down partitions. Applications can wire those http endpoints to achieve that. Everyone is welcome to contribute this feature to Pulsar. 

> I notice that Pravega will also be presented at Flink Forward in the same room, just after your presentation, perhaps you could get something more face by face :)

Sure. Happy to chat with them.
Offloading to ceph can be done though this HDFS offloader

Created the issues for the features you are interested in:

HDFS/Ceph offloader: https://github.com/apache/pulsar/issues/3216
Auto Scaling: https://github.com/apache/pulsar/issues/3217
As discussed above, Pulsar already has tiered storage in place. Closed this issue for now. Feel free to create/follow the issues that you are interested in. Contributions are warmly welcome!

@sijie  technically it's not a big impact fix, but the **default port** for zk stats is in code(not configuration), if it is changed, the upgrade could be hard and have risks in the future?
or we could change the prometheus export port ?

they both don't have many files to chnage.

I was thinking - most of the people probably don't co-run zk and bk on the same node. so we don't necessarily need to change the default zk stats port. so a simple approach might be adding a note to the deployment guide (http://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/deploy-bare-metal/#deploying-a-zookeeper-cluster) - something like: if you are planning to co-run zookeeper with bookie on the same node, you should pick up a different stats port on running zookeeper, for example:

```
PULSAR_EXTRA_OPTS="-Dstats_server_port=8001" bin/pulsar-daemon start zookeeper
```

When you mean 'thread' safe are you talking about multiple function instances updating/getting state. Yes it is, however note that if two or more instances are updating the same key, the last one will get through.

@ewh does this answer your question?
@vli02 did you ever create a PR for this?

Hey Ivan I am load balancing traffic to brokers. The target group for my load balancer is the 3 Pulsar broker instances, see attached grab from EC2
![target group](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12663894/50248819-e1894b00-03a1-11e9-8a45-8e6aa707c32a.jpeg)
@ivankelly I guess I forgot about this, sorry. I seem not able to get a chance to fix this in near future.

Is it doing L3 or L4 load balancing? When you connect to a broker to do something with a topic, usually the broker will redirect you to the broker which owns the topic. If L3 load balancing is being used here, the client will get back the redirect, and then try to connect directly. L4 _should_ handle this situation correctly.
@sijie What is the status on these now?

Hey Ivan I am not sure, I see nothing in EC2 Load Balancer info about L3 or L4. Do specific Pulsar brokers "own" topics? In any case the issue here is not with message sending or receiving but only with administrative tasks using the admin client, which seems to be incompatible with load balancers.
L3 would be network load balancer. L4 would be application load balancer.

We are using a network load balancer, looks like it does layer 4 load balancing

https://aws.amazon.com/elasticloadbalancing/features/
oh OK well then we are L3.

This is not going to be a read-modify-write as in database. In this particular scenario the final value of context.getState("key") is one of (value + "0", value + "1", value + "1" + "0", value + "0" + "1").
The only current server side support for some kind of serialization amongs't update is in form of counters. The Java API(and soon in 2.3 the python api) has support for getCounter/incrCounter methods. Using the example above, if the function logic is context.incrCounter("key", 1), and you have the guarantee that the counter.getCounter after all messages will be equal to the number of messages(assuming no failures). Hope that helps
The context.incrCounter is excellent for our use case. But the problem is that we want to store some string value in the state instead of integer. Is there any way to do that?

Try to translate the issue xinln describe: 
**Info shown on Dashboard is not accurate**

1、Follow instruction on official cookbook to deploy pulsar cluster.
2、Use command listed below to produce message to a topic 
bin/pulsar-client produce 
persistent://public/default/test 
-n 1 
-m "Hello, Pulsar"
3、Then consume the message through command listed below:
bin/pulsar-client consume persistent://public/default/test -s hei
4、Issue1, visit dashboard at http://172.19.36.119/admin/stats/topic/
It's showing lots of duplicate topic

TOPIC
persistent://public/default/test
persistent://public/default/test
persistent://public/default/test
persistent://public/default/test

Issue2、tenant, namespace and topic shown at http://172.19.36.119 is different(maybe different than what's shown in admin cli?)

@sijie I'm not sure if this pr breaks backwards compatibility. Its not changing any return types.
@srkukarni I would prefer some forms of tests to ensure it doesn't really break BC, because breaking BC is a really bad behavior to users.

@sijie I think we have already broken backwards compatibility with getFunctionInfo, getStatus, getStats endpoints in previous PRs.  To maintain backwards compatibility, I would suggest 1) merge this PR, 2) go back and move all the changes for those endpoints to V3, 3) add the old endpoints back to V2.  Add tests to make sure old clients can still talk with V2 endpoints.
I will make the changes for the assert statements not sure if we want to invest in BC tests at this time.

> getFunctionInfo, getStatus, getStats endpoints

can you gusy come up a list of endpoints that are added in 2.3.0 and those were changed in 2.3.0, before we make any decisions?

If they are new endpoints added in 2.3.0, they are okay. 
But if they are old endpoints in 2.2.0 and changed in 2.3.0, we should revert those changes and add new endpoints.

@sijie  we've waited more than 30mins
![101545357940_ pic_hd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1798683/50320570-f97adf00-0507-11e9-9ee9-64e3877ef713.jpg)
There is low chance on BC breaking , I am directly returning the object to be serialized by jersey rather than doing it explicitly.

@sijie The PR actually doesn’t change the output of any of the endpoints, its just returning the actual object to be serialized by jersey to json instead of doing that explicitly ourselves.  This PR will also make it more clear what is actually returned so it will be easier not to break backwards compatibility since currently many endpoints are just returning a Response object which is unclear what is contained within.

However, after this PR lets make sure that no changes have being introduced in the admin api so that 2.3 would break backwards compatibility for 2.2
